block.p: Sarah Louise Williams, the daughter of Carol Jo Williams and J. D. Williams of Washington, was married yesterday to Peter Lord Mali, a son of the late Jane Lawrence Mali and Henry Allen Lord Mali The Rev. Paul A. Johnson, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Meridian International Center in Washington.

The bride, 30, is a freelance writer of fiction and nonfiction and is also an adjunct professor of English at George Washington University in Washington. Ms. Williams, who is keeping her name, graduated from Yale University and received a master's of fine arts degree in creative writing from Sarah Lawrence College. Her father is a partner in Williams & Jensen, a Washington law firm. Her mother is a member of the board and a former president of the Woman's National Democratic Club in Washington.

Sarah Louise Williams, the daughter of Carol Jo Williams and J. D. Williams of Washington, was married yesterday to Peter Lord Mali, a son of the late Jane Lawrence Mali and Henry Allen Lord Mali The Rev. Paul A. Johnson, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Meridian International Center in Washington.

The bride, 30, is a freelance writer of fiction and nonfiction and is also an adjunct professor of English at George Washington University in Washington. Ms. Williams, who is keeping her name, graduated from Yale University and received a master's of fine arts degree in creative writing from Sarah Lawrence College. Her father is a partner in Williams & Jensen, a Washington law firm. Her mother is a member of the board and a former president of the Woman's National Democratic Club in Washington.

The bridegroom, 32, is a public affairs specialist and a writer for the Bureau of Land Management at the Interior Department in Washington. He graduated from Yale and received a master's degree in resource policy from the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor. His father was the vice president of H. W. T. Mali & Company, a Manhattan firm that makes billiard cloth and cues. The bridegroom's mother was an author of children's books. She was the co-author with Alison Cragin Herzig of ''Oh, Boy! Babies!'' (Little, Brown, 1980), which won a National Book Award in 1981.
